items.description: Beverley Brook area in Merton, Sutton, Kingston upon Thames, Richmond upon Thames and Wandsworth
items.eaAreaName: Kent, South London and East Sussex

floodArea.county: Greater London, Kingston upon Thames, Merton, Richmond upon Thames, Surrey, Sutton, Wandsworth
floodArea.riverOrSea: Beverley Brook, Pyl Brook, East Pyl Brook

items.message: This Flood Alert has been removed. River levels have fallen following the heavy rainfall yesterday, and no further flooding from rivers in the area is currently expected. Some standing flood water may remain in places. It should be largely dry today, Tuesday 13 July, so we do not expect further issues. We will be monitoring the situation over the coming days, though the outlook is mostly dry so no more flooding impacts are currently expected.

floodArea.county: Barnet, Enfield, Essex, Greater London, Haringey, Hertfordshire, Redbridge, Waltham Forest
floodArea.riverOrSea: Ching Brook, Cobbins Brook, Nazeing Brook, Pymmes Brook, Salmons Brook, Turkey Brook, Small River Lee, Rags Brook, Trinity Marsh Ditch

items.message: The risk of flooding from the Lower Lee tributaries has now reduced and levels have fallen below levels of concern. No further flooding to fields and roads is expected, however there may be standing water seen for several days.

Property flooding is not currently expected. River levels have risen on the River Loddon as a result of recent rainfall. Further rainfall is expected this evening, 12/07/21, therefore flooding of low lying roads and farmland is possible especially in the Longbridge Mill area. Localised heavy thunderstorms are forecast tonight although timings and locations are uncertain. It is therefore possible that river levels will continue to rise in response to the rainfall. We are closely monitoring the situation. Please remain safe and aware of your local surroundings and refer to the 'River and Sea levels in England' webpage for current river levels. This message will be updated tomorrow morning, 13/07/21, or as the situation changes.

items.description: River Brent from Hendon to Brentford

floodArea.county: Barnet, Brent, Ealing, Greater London, Hounslow

items.message: The risk of flooding from the River Brent has now reduced and levels have fallen below levels of concern. No further flooding to fields and roads is expected, however there may be standing water seen for several days.

The water level in the Eastern Yar is high and rising. In the last 24 hours, more than half a month’s rain (27mm) has been recorded at Wroxall. From 23:30 this evening, the river will begin rising towards the top of the river bank at Alverstone. Some field flooding may also occur at Langbridge. Property flooding is not expected. The rain should ease over the next few hours, clearing the Island around midnight. No more than 5mm should fall in this time. At Alverstone, the river should peak around 01:00 (13/07/21). At Sandown, the river will continue to rise until 10:00 tomorrow morning (13/07/21) at which point it might just be high enough to cause some minor impact flooding to Golf Links Road. Some showers are forecast tomorrow, so over the next 24 hours, please expect the river to be higher than normal. We continue to monitor the forecast and will remove any reported blockages from the river. Pumps used to reduce water in gardens may be required to operate. This Flood Alert will be updated by 11:00 on Tuesday 13/07/2021.

Yesterday, 1.5 times monthly average rainfall was recorded in Bishop’s Waltham. This morning (Tuesday 13/07/21), the water level in the River Hamble remains very high, but it is now falling. The river has lowered by more than a metre overnight, and the current rate of fall is 0.3m per hour. Today, the weather should remain fairly dry, with only the odd light shower forecast. This will not cause an increase in water level. Dry, warm weather is then expected for the next 5 days. Along the length of the River Hamble, significant residual flood impacts to land and some roads will continue over the next 12 hours. The situation will improve hour by hour, but the river is unlikely to return to a more typical level until later on this evening. We will continue to monitor the forecast. If it is safe to do so, flood protection (if installed) could be removed this morning. Please avoid walking or driving through flood water, and, avoid the river banks as water will be deep, fast flowing and much more dangerous than normal. We will remove this Flood Alert by 15:00 on Tuesday 13/07/2021.

items.description: Waltham Chase, Durley Mill and Botley on the River Hamble
items.message: Yesterday, 1.5 times monthly average rainfall was recorded in Bishop’s Waltham. This morning (Tuesday 13/07/21), the water level in the River Hamble remains high, but it is now falling. The river has lowered by more than a metre overnight, and the current rate of fall is 0.3m per hour. Today, the weather should remain fairly dry, with only the odd light shower forecast. This will not cause an increase in water level. Dry, warm weather is then expected for the next 5 days. Along the length of the River Hamble, significant residual flood impacts to land and some roads will continue over the next 12 hours. A Flood Alert will remain in force to cover these impacts. The situation will improve hour by hour, but the river is unlikely to return to a more typical level until later on this evening. We continue to monitor the forecast. If it is safe to do so, flood protection (if installed) could be removed this morning.
